physDesc.p: Two pages typewritten in black ink. Mrs. Richard Aldington 44 Mechlenburgh Square London, W.C. England is the typed address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Richardâ€™s book did not come for weeks after the letter about it. It finally reached me in New York a week or two ago. I kept it until I came home for reasons which I have told Richard in my letter to him, and I am sending it to Brown to-day. I think it is splendid work, but I will not duplicate what I said about it in my letter to Richard, as I want you to read that letter and if you do not think I ought to have said anything that I did, or if you think that it will trouble him, please just tear the letter up, or keep it for yourself, or send it to him mutilated and play the censor did it. The letter is meant as much for you as for him, therefore, I am not enclosing it in a separate envelope, but putting it in with yours, so that you can read all my news before sending it on to Richard.

Do write often again. I care so much to hear. You will probably be able to answer my questions about Fletcher better than Richard will. If you can find out anything without seeming to do so, I shall be eternally obliged.

I think you will like what I said about Richard in my lecture. I hope so at any rate. I shall include this paper on Richard in a volume of lectures and essays which I shall get out before long. In the meanwhile, I am hard at work on a long poem which will come out in a book of poems that I am publishing this Autumn.

Please send me a copy of "New Paths" when it comes out, as I shall be very glad to see it. You will be amused to know that one of the chapters of my "Tendencies" is to appear in the "Revue de Paris," and that a Spanish translation of my poems is to be issued in Mexico. You see, my dear, the only thing to do is to hang on. I do believe that time brings recognition, if we do not let ourselves get kicked off the tree before it comes.

This war is terribly hard. The hardest of all for you, I think. You cannot imagine how much Mrs. Russell and I think of you, and how often we speak of you, and how we wish we were there to give you the glad hand while Richard is away.
body.closer: Ever so much from us both,
